Comment: Dear China,  The reason you aren't getting an answer is because all of our politicians are waiting for the election to do anything divisive in the course of leading the country.  Our main concern isn't tariffs, it's definitely human rights and the threats to our country that Trump has made.  The fact China has been constantly threatening to invade Taiwan has always made it feel like China is going to be just another empire and is the real reason most people haven't supported you.  For the same reason, everyone is suddenly abandoning America.  The elegance of the American system was that they conceded hard power and a handful of services to attain soft power and broad support from roughly half the world.  Something some idiot was recently too stupid to comprehend.  We're all wary but hopeful China is willing to do the same.

Comment: Oh my God, the USA needs to understand that not everything is *about them*.   [Canada and China relations are not just a reaction](https://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/205/301/prime_minister-ef/jean_chretien/2003-12-08/stagingpm_3a8080/default.asp@language=e&page=newsroom&sub=speeches&doc=canadachinabcd.20010213_e.htm). Canada and China have diplomatic ties dating back to the rise of industrialized China.   The United States needs to understand that this is a them problem. The rest of the world wasn't running everything through the US. We have our own priorities, our own relationships, and frankly it's pleasant to know that we're dealing with adults who can think more than eight seconds into the future.

Comment: China has been reasonable and reliable for ages now   Theyâ€™re just not nice. Like, at all. The U.S. kind of was nice, sometimes, to white countries, and it had a lot of historical banked goodwill. All the other shit means nothing without those two, and Trump took both off the table, then smashed the table, then tried to eat the table to establish dominance.   So now China looks like a much better option. They might be kind of assholes, but they will honour a contract.

Author: sausagemouse

Comment: Nah, you're glossing over our "golden" period from 1902-1949.  We started slipping when we allowed our love for oil dominate our relationship with the Middle East and cozied up to too many strongmen during the Cold War.  World War II, the Marshall Plan and perhaps even NATO were our high point internationally.  But we have a long and dismal record in Central and South America not to mention Southeast Asia.  Our tacit support for dictatorships across the world is shameful and directly led to such anti-American rancor across the third world.  Our biggest saving grace has always been that the former Soviet Union was a  worse alternative (culturally, economically, politically) for most countries except for Cuba, North Korea, Iran and certain African nations.  I don't include the Eastern bloc which was under the yoke of Soviet hegemony.  Even there, those nations with enough remove have turned their eyes westward.

It's a decision for Canada. Progress and peace or Trump and Republicans?    Trump Tariffs Like 'Delinquent Kid Extorting Somebody'â€”Japanese Lawmaker   https://www.newsweek.com/trump-tariffs-delinquent-kid-extorting-somebody-japanese-lawmaker-2061460    >Oguma in a speech during a parliamentary committee hearing told Japanese Foreign Minister Takeshi Iwaya that the nation should resist Trump's demands, likening the U.S. approach as a "delinquent kid extorting someone," according to a Times of India translation.  >"If Japan listens to this and bends the other way in response to the impossible demands of bargaining and deals, it will set a bad example as a customary and historical precedent," Oguma said. "If you get mugged and put money in their hands, they will come back to mug us."  >Oguma called Trump's tariff formula "a mess" and questioned if it was "safe for a serious person to go there" and negotiate with the U.S.  >"Consider every option, but you should never make concessions to someone who is not straight up anyway," Oguma said, adding: "I hope that you will never give in to the American extortionists. I know this is harsh to say, but they are extortionists."  >"If you listen to what they say, it will be a really bad example," Oguma said.  >Iwaya meanwhile has called for a diplomatic approach to the still-developing U.S. trade policy, comparing the regular changes to "a daily menu." He previously called the tariffs "regrettable," according to Japanese outlet Kyodo News.
